title: 'Truth Be Told' review: Lazy and bland -- but still better than 'Dr. Ken'
text:
Comments 
A broadcast sitcom that brilliantly and hilariously delves into the treacherous terrain surrounding the use of the N word — from who's allowed to say it to what it means to different generations? ABC's "Black-ish" did it in its second season premiere last month. 
In other news, "Truth Be Told" premieres Friday night on NBC. 
Starring TV veteran Mark-Paul Gosselaar as Mitch, an ethics professor who majors in white guilt, and African-American stand-up comic Tone Bell as Russell, an African-American stand-up comic, "Truth Be Told" is being marketed as an edgy comedy about race, sex and other hot-button matters. In fact, it is a traditional laugh-track sitcom that lazily circles the taboos and only rarely scores a hit. 
Creator DJ Nash (the one-and-done "Growing Up Fisher" ) based the show on real-life experiences — he's a white guy who is married to a Korean woman and whose best friend is black. But based on the pilot, the characters on "Truth Be Told" are about as deep as the descriptions I just gave you of Nash's circle. 
There's Vanessa Hudgens as Tracy, Mitch's "ethnically ambiguous" wife, and Bresha Webb as Angie, Russell's stereotypically sassy African-American wife. TV Minute: Vicki Hyman on 'Truth Be Told' NJ.com TV critic Vicki Hyman explains why she hated the new NBC comedy 'Truth Be Told." 
They're all likeable enough, but the set-ups are straight out of a dog-eared playbook. Tracy hires a babysitter who is too distractingly hot for Mitch, turning him into the sort of drooling degenerate last spotted in a R. Crumb cartoon. Russell is jealous that Angie is still close with an ex-boyfriend. And the "candid" conversations that supposedly set this sitcom apart are barely a step above. 
The two buddies are rapping along with Jay Z to "Empire State of Mind," but Russell cuts off the song just as Mitch is about utter the N word. 
"It's just not a word that you have access to," Russell tells him. 
Mitch: "But you should hear me to do it, because I don't pronounce the 'r'!" 
These are the jokes, folks. 
Compare to "Black-ish," where even one of the premiere's tossed-off jokes about race are highly specific and telling. In a discussion about other outdated racial terms vis a vis the United Negro College Fund, Dre (Anthony Anderson) tells his boss, "Be honest — you only wrote that check so you can say Negro." 
The boss's response: "I definitely didn't do it so I can't." 
"Truth Be Told" premieres on NBC Friday 8:30 p.m. on NBC, where your alternative, sadly, is the similar misfire "Dr. Ken." Actually, "Dr. Ken," starring Ken Jeong, is even worse . NBC recently gave a surprising second season order to another race-infused sitcom "The Carmichael Show," also a traditional multi-cam comedy but with a sharper take on race. Check that out on NBC.com, or just log onto ABC.com and catch an episode of "Black-ish" instead. 
Grade: D+
